unnormalised: What are some actionable steps individuals in India can take to improve air quality in their cities and towns?
normalised: What are some actionable steps individuals in India can take to improve air quality in their cities and towns?

unnormalised: Air quality in many Indian cities, especially around Diwali time, becomes a serious concern. While large-scale policy changes are vital, individual actions can collectively make a significant difference.
normalised: Air quality in many Indian cities, especially around Diwali time, becomes a serious concern. While large-scale policy changes are vital, individual actions can collectively make a significant difference.

unnormalised: First, consider your transportation choices. Opt for public transport like the Delhi Metro or the Mumbai local train whenever possible. Cycling or walking short distances not only improves air quality but also benefits your health. Encourage carpooling within your office or neighborhood – maybe even start a "buddy system"!
normalised: First, consider your transportation choices. Opt for public transport like the Delhi Metro or the Mumbai local train whenever possible. Cycling or walking short distances not only improves air quality but also benefits your health. Encourage carpooling within your office or neighborhood – maybe even start a "buddy system"!

unnormalised: Second, be mindful of your energy consumption. Reduce your electricity usage by switching to LED bulbs and turning off appliances when not in use. Promote the use of solar energy in your community; even rooftop solar panels on a few houses can have a cumulative impact.
normalised: Second, be mindful of your energy consumption. Reduce your electricity usage by switching to L E D bulbs and turning off appliances when not in use. Promote the use of solar energy in your community; even rooftop solar panels on a few houses can have a cumulative impact.

unnormalised: Third, avoid burning garbage, leaves, or other materials. Open burning contributes significantly to particulate matter. Encourage proper waste segregation in your locality and compost organic waste. Think about reducing your dependence on wood-fired stoves; if you use them, ensure proper ventilation.
normalised: Third, avoid burning garbage, leaves, or other materials. Open burning contributes significantly to particulate matter. Encourage proper waste segregation in your locality and compost organic waste. Think about reducing your dependence on wood-fired stoves; if you use them, ensure proper ventilation.

unnormalised: Fourth, plant more trees and support urban forestry initiatives. Trees absorb pollutants and release oxygen. Participate in tree plantation drives organized by NGOs like Green Yatra.
normalised: Fourth, plant more trees and support urban forestry initiatives. Trees absorb pollutants and release oxygen. Participate in tree plantation drives organized by N G O s like Green Yatra.

unnormalised: Fifth, be a conscious consumer. Support businesses that prioritize environmental sustainability. Reduce your consumption of single-use plastics.
normalised: Fifth, be a conscious consumer. Support businesses that prioritize environmental sustainability. Reduce your consumption of single-use plastics.

unnormalised: Finally, spread awareness! Talk to your family, friends, and neighbors about the importance of air quality and the small steps they can take. During festivals like Onam, opt for eco-friendly decorations and practices. Remember, breathing clean air is our fundamental right, and it requires a collective effort. Even small changes can help us enjoy a delicious plate of biryani without worrying about the smog outside!
